com.ibm.xmi.framework
Class XMIFile

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.xmi.framework.XMIFile
public class XMIFile
extends java.lang.Object

This class represents an XMI file. You make an instance of this class and invoke its write method to create an XMI file; when you load an XMI file, the framework makes an instance of this class, then you can query the file for the objects and header information from the XMI file.

The major sections of an XMI file are: header, content, extensions, and differences. The header contains information about the data in the file, the content contains your objects, the extensions section contains data that does not match the model for the objects in the contents section, and the differences section contains differences to be applied to a base XMI file.

The framework currently ignores the extensions and differences sections of XMI files, although it lets you work with XMI extensions for your objects that are in the content sections of XMI files.

By default, the framework sets the exporter and exporterVersion in the header to be "XMI Application Framework" and "1.19", respectively, to identify that this software created the file. You can set your own values for the exporter and exporter version, or set them to null. If you set them to null and don't set other header data, the framework does not write a header at all.

The framework handles XMI 1.0 and XMI 1.1 files. By default, XMI files are set to version 1.0, but you can call the setXMIVersion method to set the XMI version to 1.1.

You can create an XMI file for a file name, output stream, or zip output stream.

By default, the encoding for the XMI file is UTF-8, and nested XML elements are indented two spaces, but you can change these settings.

If you use the DEFAULT option for loading and writing XMI files, the header elements are processed. If you use the OBJECTS_ONLY option for writing XMI files, only the content of the XMI.content element is written; the XMI XML element and the XMI.header are not written. If you specify OBJECTS_ONLY during load, the framework assumes that the only XML elements in the file are those that would normally be in the XMI.content XML element.

Inner Class Summary
static class XMIFile.Import
          An import is part of the header of an XMI file that identifies other files that are needed to work with the objects in an XMI file.
static class XMIFile.Metametamodel
          A metametamodel is part of the header of an XMI file that represents the metametamodel for the objects in the file.
static class XMIFile.Metamodel
          A metamodel is part of the header of an XMI file that represents the metamodel for the objects in the file.
static class XMIFile.Model
          A model is part of the header of an XMI file that represents the model for the objects in the file.

Constructor Detail

XMIFile

public XMIFile(java.io.OutputStream o,
               java.lang.String filename)
Create an XMIFile object corresponding to the given file name and output stream. The filename is used by the framework to determine whether a reference to another object is a cross-file reference. The framework will not close the output stream at the end of the write method. The filename must not be null or the empty string.
Parameters:
o - An output stream that you open
filename - The file name

XMIFile

public XMIFile(java.lang.String filename)
Create an XMIFile object corresponding to the given file name.
Parameters:
filename - The name of the file to open

XMIFile

public XMIFile(java.util.zip.ZipOutputStream zos,
               java.lang.String entry)
Create an XMI file that will be a zip entry in a ZipOutputStream. You are responsible for closing the zip output stream, since you may want to put multiple XMI files into one zip file.

To put multiple XMI files into one zip file, open a zip output stream, then create XMI file objects with the same zip output stream to create the entries you want. After you have created all of the entries, close the zip output stream.

Parameters:
zos - The zip output stream
entry - The entry for the zip file

add

public void add(Namespace n)
Add the namespace to the header for this XMI file; you normally do not need to call this method, since the framework will add the namespaces for your objects to the file automatically when you call the write method.

You can have multiple XML namespaces in one XMI 1.1 file. If you are writing an XMI 1.0 file, the namespaces are ignored.

Parameters:
n - A namespace to put in the header for this XMI file

isVerified

public boolean isVerified()
XMI files can indicate that they have been verified; doing so may allow tools that use those files to do less checking of the contents of the files than they would normally do. By default, this is false for XMI files.
Returns:
True if the XMI file has been verified; false otherwise.

load

public static XMIFile load(java.lang.String filename,
                           int option,
                           boolean validate)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
This method loads an XMI file, puts the data in the file into an XMIFile object, and returns the XMIFile object so you can retrieve the data.

There is only one option currently available for loading, XMIFile.DEFAULT, but other options may be added in the future.

If a SAX parser exception occurs when loading, the load stops.

By default if you use this method, the framework does not know the model that defines the data in the XMI file, so the XMI objects you get from the XMI file will have values of Value.DATA and Value.OBJECT type.

If your objects have values of type Value.REFERENCE, Value.CONTAINER, or Value.CONTAINED when you create an XMI 1.0 file, and you use this method to load the file, the framework makes a value of type Value.OBJECT for each value.

If your objects have values of type Value.REFERENCE, Value.CONTAINER, or Value.CONTAINED when you create an XMI 1.1 file, and you use this method to load the file, the framework makes a value of type Value.OBJECT for each value of type Value.CONTAINED and a value of type Value.DATA for Value.REFERENCE and Value.CONTAINER values. The values of the Value.DATA value objects for Value.REFERENCE and Value.CONTAINER values are strings containing XML idrefs separated by spaces.

For both XMI 1.0 and XMI 1.1, a Value.DATA value is created during a load for each value that was initially a Value.ENUM value.

To restore all values, you need to use a workspace. See the Workspace class documentation for more details.

You can implement a reader adapter that will be able to restore values in your files even if you use this method to do a load. For more details, see the ReaderAdapter interface documentation.

Parameters:
filename - The file name of the XMI file
option - Curently, DEFAULT is the only available option
validate - If true, a validating SAX parser is used; if false, a nonvalidating SAX parser is used
Returns:
The XMIFile object containing the data from the XMI file

load

public static XMIFile load(java.lang.String filename,
                           java.io.InputStream stream,
                           int option,
                           boolean validate)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
This method is identical to the previous method except that you can provide an input stream that you have opened already. The stream will be used to load the XMI file.

Please see the other load method of this class for more details about how the framework loads XMI files.

Parameters:
filename - The file name of the XMI file
stream - An open input stream to use when loading the file
option - Curently, DEFAULT is the only available option
validate - If true, a validating SAX parser is used; if false, a nonvalidating SAX parser is used
Returns:
The XMIFile object containing the data from the XMI file

setIndent

public void setIndent(int indent)
By default, XML elements contained in other XML elements are indented two spaces when an XMI file is written. You can adjust the number of spaces the framework indents using this method. If you indent is 0, the framework does not indent XML elements inside XML elements.
Parameters:
indent - How many spaces to indent XML elements

setTimestamp

public void setTimestamp(java.lang.String t)
This method lets you set the timestamp the framework puts in an XMI file. By default, the framework will generate a timestamp and put it in the XMI file, so you do not need to set one yourself. You can also use the setPrintTimestamp method to tell the framework not to put a timestamp in the XMI file.
Parameters:
t - The timestamp to put in the XMI file.

setXMIFiles

public void setXMIFiles(XMIFiles f)
This method sets the XMIFiles object associated with the XMI file. If you load an XMI file using one of the load methods in the XMIFiles class, the framework automatically sets this for you, so you normally do not need to use this method.
Parameters:
f - The XMIFiles object associated with this XMI file

setXMIVersion

public void setXMIVersion(java.lang.String v)
You can use this method to set the XMI version of an XMI file to either 1.0 or 1.1. By default, an XMI file has XMI version set to 1.0.
Parameters:
v - Either 1.0 or 1.1

setVerified

public void setVerified(boolean v)
This method lets you set the verified XML attribute for the XMI element in an XMI file. If true, it indicates that the XMI file contents have been validated; if false, no validation has been done. The default value is true.
Parameters:
v - True or false

setPrintTimestamp

public void setPrintTimestamp(boolean value)
If printTimestamp is set to true, the framework will print a timestamp; otherwise, the framework will not print a timestamp. The default value is true.
Parameters:
value - True to print a timestamp, false otherwise.

write

public void write(java.util.Iterator topObjects,
                  int option)
           throws java.lang.Exception
This method writes the top objects, those objects not contained in other objects, to the XMI file, along with header data you set before calling this method. You can control whether the framework makes a header for the XMI file, the content of the header, whether the framework generates a timestamp, and whether the framework indents XML elements inside other XML elements.

By default, the framework generates a timestamp containing the date and time the XMI file was written, indents two spaces, and generates a header that has the exporter set to "XMI Framework" and the exporter version set to "1.2".

The framework writes all top objects and contained objects (values of type Value.CONTAINED and Value.OBJECT) to the file.

You may put objects in the top objects collection only if those objects are not contained in other objects. If you put a contained object in the top objects collection, the object will be written twice.

It is also your responsibility to put an object in the top objects collection if it is related to an object saved in the file. If you do not put these objects in the top objects collection, the object will not be saved in the XMI file.

Parameters:
topObjects - Objects that are not contained by other objects in this file
option - Currently, the only available option is XMIFile.DEFAULT.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
The string representation of an XMI file is as follows: "filename: " filename " entry: " entry
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
The string representation of the XMI file
